facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 226 of 1959 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 226 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 23, 1958 of Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 87 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 23, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 87 of 1957.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the appellant's appeal against his conviction under s. 420 read with s. 511 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the High Court at Patna dismissing the appellants appeal against his conviction under s. 420, read with s. 511, of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Patna University for permission to appear at the 1954 M.A. Examination in English as a private candidate.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the Patna University for permission to appear at the 1954 M. A. Examination in English as a private candidate, representing that he was a graduate

facts.text: Appellant represented that he was a graduate having obtained B.A. Degree in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: representing that he was a graduate having obtained his B.A. Degree in 1951 and that he had been teaching in a certain school.

facts.text: Appellant represented that he had been teaching in a certain school.

anchor.surface_text: having obtained his B.A. Degree in 1951 and that he had been teaching in a certain school. In support of his application,

facts.text: Appellant attached certificates purporting to be from the Headmaster of the School and the Inspector of Schools to his application.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his application, he attached certain certificates purporting to be from the Headmaster of the School, and the Inspector of Schools.

facts.text: University authorities accepted appellant's statements and gave permission, and asked for fees and two copies of his photograph.

anchor.surface_text: The University authorities accepted the appellants statements and gave permission and wrote to him asking for the remission of the fees and two copies of his photograph.

facts.text: Appellant furnished the fees and two copies of his photograph.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant furnished these and on April 9, 1954, proper admission card for him was despatched to the Headmaster of the School.

facts.text: On April 9, 1954, admission card was despatched to the Headmaster of the School.

anchor.surface_text: and on April 9, 1954, proper admission card for him was despatched to the Headmaster of the School. Information reached the University

facts.text: Information reached the University that the appellant was not a graduate and not a teacher.

anchor.surface_text: Information reached the University about the appellants being not a graduate and being not a teacher. Inquiries were made and it was found

facts.text: Certificates attached to the application were forged.

anchor.surface_text: Inquiries were made and it was found that the certificates attached to the application were forged, that the appellant was not a graduate and was not a teacher

facts.text: Appellant was not a graduate and was not a teacher.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was not a graduate and was not a teacher and that in fact he had been de-barred from taking any University examination

facts.text: Appellant had been de-barred from taking any University examination for a certain number of years due to malpractice at a University examination.

anchor.surface_text: and that in fact he had been de-barred from taking any University examination for a certain number of years on account of his having committed malpractice at a University examination.

facts.text: Matter was reported to the police, which investigated and prosecuted the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In consequence, the matter was reported to the police which, on investigation, prosecuted the appellant. The appellant was acquitted of the charge

facts.text: Appellant was acquitted of the charge of forging the certificates.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was acquitted of the charge of forging those certificates, but was convicted of the offence of attempting to cheat

facts.text: Appellant was convicted of attempting to cheat the University by false representations inducing issuance of admission card.

anchor.surface_text: but was convicted of the offence of attempting to cheat inasmuch as he, by false representations, deceived the University and induced the authorities to issue the admission card,

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on April 24, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-This appeal,

facts.text: Appellant deceived the University by false statements about being a graduate and teacher.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the appellant, by making false statements about his being a graduate and a teacher, in the applications he had submitted to the University, did deceive the University

facts.text: Fraud was detected before admission card was delivered to appellant due to information reaching the University.

anchor.surface_text: He just failed to get it and sit for the examination because something beyond his control took place inasmuch as the University was informed about his being neither a graduate nor a teacher.

arguments.claim: the first step in the commission of the offence of cheating must be an act which would lead to the deception of the person sought to be cheated; submitting false application is such act

anchor.surface_text: The first step in the companymission of the offence of cheating, therefore, must be an act which would lead to the deception of the person sought to be cheated. The moment a person takes some step to deceive the person sought to be cheated, he has embarked on a companyrse of companyduct which is numberhing less than an attempt to companymit the offence

arguments.claim: cases relied by appellant such as Queen v. Paterson, Regina v. Padala Venkatasami do not express different view on s.511 construction

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant relied on certain cases in support of his companytention. They are number much to the point and do number in fact express any different opinion about the companystruction to be placed on the provisions of s. 511, Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: a person commits attempt when he intends the offence and does an act towards its commission after preparations; such act need not be penultimate

anchor.surface_text: We may summarise our views about the companystruction of s. 511, Indian Penal Code, thus A personal companymits the offence of attempt to companymit a particular offence when  i  he intends to companymit that particular offence and  ii  he, having made preparations and with the intention to companymit the offence, does an act towards its companymission such an act need number be the penultimate act

arguments.claim: in present case, appellant's acts amount to attempt: prepared and dispatched application, remitted fees, sent photos, induced issuance of card

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant intended to deceive the University and obtain the necessary permission and the admission card and, number only sent an application for permission to sit at the University examination, but also followed it up, on getting the necessary permission, by remitting the necessary fees and sending the companyies of his photograph, on the receipt of which the University did issue the admission card.

holdings.text: The admission card is property for the purposes of the offence of cheating under s. 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the appellant, by making false statements about his being a graduate and a teacher, in the applications he had submitted to the University, did deceive the University and that his intention was to make the University give him permission and deliver to him the admission card which would have enabled him to sit for the M.A. Examination. This card is Property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission card has immense value to candidate enabling entry to exam hall despite no pecuniary value; cites precedents like Queen Empress v. Appasami and Queen Empress v. Soshi Bhushan holding similar items as property.

holdings.text: The appellant deceived the University by false statements and induced delivery of the admission card, amounting to cheating if not detected.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the appellant, by making false statements about his being a graduate and a teacher, in the applications he had submitted to the University, did deceive the University and that his intention was to make the University give him permission and deliver to him the admission card

holdings.reasoning_summary: False representations about graduation and teaching deceived authorities into issuing permission and card; card qualifies as property induced by deception per s.415 IPC.

holdings.text: Under s.511 IPC, attempt to commit offence begins after preparations are complete when accused does any act towards commission during course of committing, not limited to penultimate act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of s.511; approves wide scope covering series of acts; distinguishes English law; cites and approves cases like R. MacCrea emphasizing acts conducive to commission.

holdings.text: Appellant's actspreparing and dispatching false application, remitting fees, sending photographsconstitute attempt to cheat beyond mere preparation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Preparation complete with application; dispatch and subsequent acts (fees, photos) are steps towards commission leading to deception and issuance of card; fraud detected before delivery but attempt complete.

holdings.text: Submitting a false application is an attempt to cheat as it is the first step leading to deception of the person sought to be cheated.

anchor.surface_text: The first step in the commission of the offence of cheating, therefore, must be an act which would lead to the deception of the person sought to be cheated. The moment a person takes some step to deceive the person sought to be cheated, he has embarked on a course of conduct which is nothing less than an attempt to commit the offence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act must lead to deception; application with false statements embarks on course of attempt per s.511; dependent on facts and nature of offence.

anchor.surface_text: In Queen Empress v. Appasami  1  it was held that the ticket entitling the accused to enter the examination room and be there examined for the Matriculation test of the University was property.

precedents.cited_proposition: ticket entitling the accused to enter the examination room and be there examined for the Matriculation test of the University was property

anchor.surface_text: In Queen Empress v. Soshi Bhushan  2  it was held that the term property in s. 463, Indian Penal Code, included the written certificate to the effect that the accused had attended, during a certain period, a course of law lectures and had paid up his fees.

precedents.cited_proposition: term property in s. 463, Indian Penal Code, included the written certificate to the effect that the accused had attended [...] a course of law lectures and had paid up his fees
precedents.cited_holding: property includes written certificate of attendance and fees payment

anchor.surface_text: In The Queen v. Ramsarun Chowbey  1  it was said at p. 47 To constitute then the offence of attempt under this section  s. 511 , there must be an act done with the intention of committing an offence, and for the purpose of committing that offence, and it must be done in attempting the commission of the offence.

precedents.cited_proposition: to constitute offence of attempt under s. 511 there must be an act done with intention of committing offence for purpose of committing it and done in attempting commission
precedents.cited_holding: act must lead immediately to commission though not necessary constituent

precedents.citation: In the matter of the petition of R. MacCrea  1

anchor.surface_text: In In the matter of the petition of R. MacCrea  1  it was held that whether any given act or series of acts amounted to an attempt which the law would take notice of or merely to preparation, was a question of fact in each case and that s. 511 was not meant to cover only the penultimate act towards the completion of an offence nor acts precedent

precedents.case_name: In the matter of the petition of R. MacCrea
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 511 covers acts in course of attempt not only penultimate act; attempt may comprise series of acts
precedents.cited_holding: any act conducive to commission during attempt is punishable

anchor.surface_text: In Queen v. Paterson  1  the publication of banns of marriage was not held to amount to an attempt to commit the offence of bigamy under s. 494, Indian Penal Code. It was observed at p. 317 The publication of banns may, or may not be, in cases in which a special license is not obtained.

precedents.cited_proposition: publication of banns not attempt to commit bigamy
precedents.cited_holding: publication of banns or procuring license not part of marriage ceremony

anchor.surface_text: In Regina v. Padala Venkatasami  1  the preparation of a copy of an intended false document, together with the purchase of stamped paper for the purpose of writing that false document and the securing of information about the facts to be inserted in the document, were held not to amount to an attempt to commit forgery

precedents.cited_proposition: preparing copy of false document, buying stamp paper, securing info not attempt to forgery
precedents.cited_holding: not proceeded to do act towards commission of forgery

precedents.citation: In the matter of the petition of Riasat Ali  2

anchor.surface_text: In In the matter of the petition of Riasat Ali  2  the accuseds ordering the printing of one hundred receipt forms similar to those used by a company and his correcting proofs of those forms were not held to amount to his attempting to commit forgery

precedents.case_name: In the matter of the petition of Riasat Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: ordering printing of receipt forms and correcting proofs not attempt to forgery without seal/signature
precedents.cited_holding: not done act towards making form false document

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge quoted what Lord Blackburn said in Reg. v. Chessman  3   1   1881  I.L.R. 3 Mad. 4.  2   1881  I.L.R. 7 Cal. 352. Lee Caves Rep. 145. There is no doubt a difference between the preparation antecedent to an offence and the actual attempt but if the actual transaction has commenced, which would have ended in the crime if not interrupted, there is clearly an attempt to commit the crime.

precedents.cited_proposition: if actual transaction commenced which would end in crime if not interrupted, it is attempt

anchor.surface_text: He also quoted what Cockburn, C. J., said in MPher sons Case  1  The word attempt clearly conveys with it the idea, that if the attempt had succeeded, the offence charged would have been committed. An attempt must be to do that which, if successful, would amount to the felony charged.

precedents.cited_proposition: attempt conveys that if succeeded offence would be committed

precedents.citation: In re Amrita Bazar Patrika Press Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In In re Amrita Bazar Patrika Press Ltd. Mukherjee, J., said at p. 234 In the language of Stephen  Digest of Criminal Law, Art. 50 , an attempt to commit a crime is an act done with an intent to commit that crime and forming part of a series of acts which would constitute its actual commission if it were not interrupted.

precedents.case_name: In re Amrita Bazar Patrika Press Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: attempt is act with intent forming part of series which would constitute commission if not interrupted

anchor.surface_text: Reg. v. Collins This again is not consistent with what is laid down in s. 511 and not also with what the law in England is. In Stephens Digest of Criminal Law, 9th Edition, attempt is defined thus Dears B. 202.

precedents.cited_proposition: attempt if not prevented would result in full consummation

anchor.surface_text: In In re T. Munirathnam Reddi  1  it was said at p. 122 The distinction between preparation and attempt may be clear in some cases, but, in most of the cases, the dividing line is very thin. Nonetheless, it is a real distinction. The crucial test is whether the last act, if uninterrupted and successful, would constitute a crime.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between preparation and attempt; crucial test whether last act if successful would constitute crime
precedents.cited_holding: observations in context of attempt to murder by shooting

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the appellant intended to deceive the University and obtain the necessary permission and the admission card and, number only sent an application for permission to sit at the University examination, but also followed it up, on getting the necessary permission, by remitting the necessary fees and sending the companyies of his photograph, on the receipt of which the University did issue the admission card. There is therefore hardly any scope for saying that what the appellant had actually done did number amount to his attempting to companymit the offence and had number gone beyond the stage of preparation.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the appellant, by making false statements about his being a graduate and a teacher, in the applications he had submitted to the University, did deceive the University and that his intention was to make the University give him permission and deliver to him the admission card which would have enabled him to sit for the M.A. Examination. anchor.surface_text: The first step in the commission of the offence of cheating, therefore, must be an act which would lead to the deception of the person sought to be cheated.
